misconceptions.name: Adding denominators
misconceptions.description: Adding the denominators when adding fractions instead of finding a common denominator.
misconceptions.remediation_template: When adding fractions, you need a COMMON denominator first. Only the numerators (top numbers) get added. The denominator stays the same once both fractions share it.

misconceptions.name: Forgetting to convert
misconceptions.description: Not converting fractions to have the same denominator before adding or subtracting.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Before adding or subtracting fractions, convert them to have the same denominator. Find the least common multiple (LCM) of both denominators, then adjust each fraction.

misconceptions.name: Adding numerators AND denominators
misconceptions.description: Adding both the top and bottom numbers separately when adding fractions.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Only numerators get added! The denominator represents the size of each piece. You can't add pieces of different sizes directly - first make them the same size (common denominator).

misconceptions.name: Subtraction direction error
misconceptions.description: Subtracting in the wrong order or confusing which number to subtract from which.
misconceptions.remediation_template: In subtraction, order matters! The first fraction minus the second. Line them up carefully and subtract numerators in the correct order.

misconceptions.name: Equivalent fraction confusion
misconceptions.description: Not understanding that equivalent fractions represent the same value.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Equivalent fractions show the same amount! 2/4 = 1/2 because if you divide both top and bottom by 2, you get 1/2. Think of pizza slices - 2 out of 4 slices is the same as 1 out of 2.

misconceptions.name: Simplification error
misconceptions.description: Incorrectly simplifying fractions or not recognizing when to simplify.
misconceptions.remediation_template: To simplify, divide BOTH the numerator and denominator by the same number (their GCF). 2/4 ÷ 2/2 = 1/2. Both parts must be divided by the same amount!

misconceptions.name: Sign confusion in addition
misconceptions.description: Confusing when to add vs subtract when dealing with negative numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Think of the number line! Adding a negative moves LEFT. Adding a positive moves RIGHT. -5 + 3 means start at -5 and move 3 steps right → land on -2.

misconceptions.name: Ignoring the negative sign
misconceptions.description: Treating negative numbers as positive or ignoring the negative sign entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_template: The negative sign is crucial! It tells you which side of zero you're on. Always write and track the negative signs carefully throughout your calculation.

misconceptions.name: Double negative confusion
misconceptions.description: Not understanding that subtracting a negative is the same as adding.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Subtracting a negative = adding a positive! Think: 5 - (-3) = 5 + 3 = 8. The two negatives 'cancel out' and become a plus.

misconceptions.name: Subtraction as 'making smaller'
misconceptions.description: Thinking subtraction always makes numbers smaller, even with negatives.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Subtracting moves LEFT on the number line. Starting at -4 and subtracting 6 moves 6 steps left: -4 → -10. With negatives, you can get 'more negative' (smaller).

misconceptions.name: Multiplication sign rules
misconceptions.description: Not applying correct sign rules when multiplying negatives.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Sign rules for multiplication: Positive × Positive = Positive. Negative × Negative = Positive. Positive × Negative = Negative. Count the negatives - even count = positive result!

misconceptions.name: Magnitude vs sign error
misconceptions.description: Getting the correct magnitude but wrong sign, or vice versa.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Calculate the magnitude (the number) first, THEN determine the sign. For (-3) × (-4): magnitude is 3 × 4 = 12. Sign: negative × negative = positive. Answer: +12.

misconceptions.name: Inverse operation error
misconceptions.description: Using the wrong inverse operation (adding instead of subtracting, etc.).
misconceptions.remediation_template: Use the OPPOSITE operation to isolate x. If the equation has +5, subtract 5 from both sides. If it has ×3, divide both sides by 3. Undo what's being done to x!

misconceptions.name: One-sided operation
misconceptions.description: Performing the operation on only one side of the equation.
misconceptions.remediation_template: An equation is like a balance scale - whatever you do to one side, you MUST do to the other! If you subtract 5 from the left, subtract 5 from the right too.

misconceptions.name: Order of operations confusion
misconceptions.description: Not following correct order when solving multi-step equations.
misconceptions.remediation_template: For two-step equations: First undo addition/subtraction, THEN undo multiplication/division. Work 'outward' from the variable. 2x + 4 = 10 → subtract 4 first → 2x = 6 → then divide by 2.

misconceptions.name: Coefficient confusion
misconceptions.description: Not properly handling the coefficient when isolating the variable.
misconceptions.remediation_template: The coefficient is the number multiplied by x. To remove it, divide BOTH sides by that number. 3x = 15 → divide both sides by 3 → x = 5.

misconceptions.name: Arithmetic error in solving
misconceptions.description: Making basic arithmetic mistakes while solving correctly set up equations.
misconceptions.remediation_template: Your method is right! Just double-check your arithmetic. Work slowly and verify each step. Try plugging your answer back into the original equation to check.
